title: Proposition bet
text:
In <a href="gambling">gambling</a>, a "proposition bet" (prop bet, prop, novelty, or a side bet) is a bet made regarding the occurrence or non-occurrence during a game (usually a gambling game) of an event not directly affecting the game's final outcome.
Proposition bets in sports are differentiated from the general bets for or against a particular team or regarding the total number of points scored. Traditionally, proposition bets can be made on outcomes such as the number of strikeouts a <a href="pitcher">pitcher</a> will accumulate in a <a href="baseball">baseball</a> game, whether a non-<a href="American%20football%20positions%23Offense">offensive</a> player will score in an <a href="American%20football">American football</a> game, which team will score the first points of the game, the discipline record of teams in a match, the timing of certain events, the number of specific events per team or in the entire match, realistically any statistically discrete event contained in a match or game could be bet on.
Fixing part of a match for a certain result in a proposition bet is called <a href="spot-fixing">spot-fixing</a>.

Dare for money.
Less commonly, "proposition bet" (in this context also "one-of-a-kind bet") denotes a dare for money. The bet is on whether the "dared" person will make a given event happen. If the "dared" person accepts the bet, they will collect if they succeed or pay if they fail.
For an example detailed in the book "<a href="The%20Professor%2C%20the%20Banker%2C%20and%20the%20Suicide%20King">The Professor, the Banker, and the Suicide King</a>", <a href="David%20Grey">David Grey</a> once bet <a href="Howard%20Lederer">Howard Lederer</a>, a professional poker player who became <a href="vegetarian">vegetarian</a> following <a href="gastric%20bypass%20surgery">gastric bypass surgery</a>, $10,000 that Lederer would not eat an offered <a href="cheeseburger">cheeseburger</a>. Lederer accepted the wager, ate the cheeseburger, and won the bet.
Spot fixing.
<a href="Spot-fixing">Spot-fixing</a> is an illegal activity where a person involved in the game takes steps to ensure a certain result for a proposition bet. Instead of fixing an entire match, or shaving points, spot fixing can be done with as little as one player, and can involve ensuring a certain outcome on only a single play, and may be completely unrelated to the points/results in a game.
Examples include <a href="Matt%20Le%20Tissier">Matt Le Tissier</a> attempting to fix the time of a <a href="throw-in">throw-in</a> by kicking it out immediately after the game started, or <a href="Ryan%20Tandy">Ryan Tandy</a> attempting to fix the first <a href="rugby%20league%20gameplay%23Point_scoring">point scored method</a> in a <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> game, failing after the opposition decided against kicking a penalty goal and instead scored a try. Multiple <a href="cricket">cricket</a> players on teams at all levels of the sport have also attempted to fix events, such as the number of <a href="wide%20%28cricket%29">wides</a> or <a href="no-ball">no-ball</a>s in an over or the number of runs scored.
The fact that these minor events often contribute a minor or non-existent impact on the score or result of a game makes recruiting players for spot fixing an easier attraction than attempting to fix an entire match that may consist of dozens of players.
